This breed is named a "Singing Dog" because of its unique ability to fluctuate the tone of its voice, resulting in a "singing" sound.

details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsHip dysplasia; subaortic stenosis; chronic drooling; easy weight gain that adds pressure to large frame.
details.history: History and Facts: The exact origins of the Newfoundland are unknown, but it is suspected that it could descend from a cross of native Canadian Hounds, the now-extinct Greater St. John's Dog, the Labrador Retriever and / or the Tibetan Mastiff. The resulting breed was favored by fisherman in Newfoundland because it was adept at swimming and retrieving. These dogs would help fishermen retrieve nets and other items from the water. Today, the Newfoundland is a popular companion and is used in some countries as an official water rescue dog.

special.exercise: The Newfoundland will be lazy if left to its own devices. Moderate exercise, such as walk and play, are required to help this breed stay fit and trim. This dog generally likes to swim.
special.grooming: Regular brushing is required to keep your Newfoundland's shedding under control. Occasional dry shampooing is recommended.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorThis breed is intelligent, good-natured, and "almost human." The Newfoundland is a gentle giant, but may be aggressive with other male dogs. This breed generally gets along with female dogs and small pets. The Newfoundland loves children and will be extremely protective of them (and adults). If a family member is threatened, the Newfoundland is likely to place itself between the intruder and the person being threatened. This breed is sociable and wants to be with people all of the time, especially when outdoors.

details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsExcellent health record. No known hereditary conditions.
details.history: History and Facts: Originally the Norfolk and Norwich Terrier were considered the same dog. However, differences in the ears and body shape led to the two being recognized separately. The Norfolk is the thinner of the two and has dropped instead of pricked ears.

special.exercise: The Norfolk Terrier will make a good jogging companion, as long as the jogs are short.
special.grooming: No special grooming requirements.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorThis is a lively, affectionate and well-balanced dog. This breed is one of the most calm of all the terriers. The breed is easy to train as long as owners are consistent and patient. However, it can be difficult to housebreak. The Norfolk Terrier has tendency to dig and shouldn't be left outside without supervision; it may dig right under your fence and escape. This breed should be kept on a leash when in public because it may provoke a dog fight. At home, the Norfolk Terrier can get along with other pets (as long as it has been raised with them from an early age). Highly sociable, these dogs love everyone in the family -- especially kids.

details.aka: Also know as: Norsk Buhund, Norwegian Sheepdog
details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsHip dysplasia; eye problems
details.history: History and Facts: A descendant of ancient Nordic hounds, the Buhund was originally used for sledding, herding and hunting. Today, it makes an excellent family pet and guard for the family property.
details.role: Today's Role: Companion Dog, Guard Dog, Herding

special.exercise: Due to its working nature, the Norwegian Buhund requires daily exercise consisting of long walks, jogs, romps or play sessions. This breed loves to run in a fenced yard.
special.grooming: No special grooming requirements.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorIntelligent, attentive and loveable, this breed learns quickly and considers training fun. Norwegian Buhunds are highly active and will require plenty of exercise and attention. The breed is prone to barking and will do so to communicate with its owner. While the Norwegian Buhund can be stubborn, it is also easy-going and will not bite or snap unless provoked.

details.aka: Also know as: Norsk Elghund, Elkhound, Grahund , Swedish Gray Dog
details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsHip dysplasia; pyotraumatic dermatitis (skin irritation caused and made worse by biting, scratching and licking); progressive retinal atrophy; Fanconi Syndrome (kidney malfunction causing extreme thirst and urine production); easy weight gain
details.history: History and Facts: The Elkhound is the national breed of Norway. It is an ancient breed that used to accompany the Vikings on hunting expeditions. In the 1800s, the current standards were developed for this breed. In addition to the Gray Elkhound, breeders also developed a smaller, black version called the Black Norwegian Elkhound. Both are similar in personality and stature.
details.role: Today's Role: Companion Dog, Guard Dog, Hunting

special.exercise: The Norwegian Elkhound requires strenuous activity daily, such as running.
special.grooming: No special grooming requirements.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorThe Norwegian Elkhound is enthusiastic, friendly and gets along well with children. Affectionate and loyal, this breed has a mind of its own. Consistency and patience in training works best. Avoid scolding this breed, because it's sensitive and may "pout" for several days if it feels it was unjustly disciplined. Norwegian Elkhounds have a tendency to roam because; these dogs pick up interesting scents and decide to follow them. Keep on a leash or fenced in when outside -- or your Elkhound will get easily distracted.

details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsHip dysplasia; genetic eye diseases; epilepsy; back problems
details.history: History and Facts: The Norwich Terrier originated as a small ratting dog in England. It was able to get in and out of burrows easily because of its small size. During fox hunts, it was also utilized for bolting foxes.

special.exercise: Norwich Terriers are energetic little dogs. A daily walk is recommended.
special.grooming: The Norwich Terrier has a medium length coat that needs frequent brushing. Bathe when necessary.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorActive and affectionate, the Norwich Terrier loves to be around people. Norwich Terriers have plenty of energy and need stimulation to keep occupied. Even though this dog is highly active, it is not prone to nervousness. This breed enjoys playing with toys and interacts well with other pets.

details.aka: Also know as: Little Red Duck Dog, Little River Duck Dog, Yarouth Toller
details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsHip dysplasia; progressive retinal atrophy; hypothyroidism; autoimmune disorders
details.history: History and Facts: This intelligent breed was developed by Canadian hunters. Crossed with Retrievers and working Spaniels, the Nova Scotia Duck-Tolling Retriever's job was to lure ducks and geese within shotgun range and to retrieve them from the water.

special.exercise: The Nova Scotia Duck-Tolling Retriever requires plenty of exercise. This dog will enjoy retrieving sticks or balls.
special.grooming: Your Nova Scotia Duck-Tolling Retriever's water-repellent, double coat should be brushed frequently. Bathe when necessary.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorThe Nova Scotia Suck-Tolling Retriever makes an excellent companion as long as it receives sufficient exercise. This intelligent animal is easy to train and devoted to its family. However, this breed is reserved around strangers. A playful and hard-working personality makes it an ideal dog for luring or tolling water fowl.

details.aka: Also know as: Old Danish Birddog, Gammel Dansk Honsehund
details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsExcellent health record. No known hereditary conditions.
details.history: History and Facts: Morten Bak from Denmark began crossing local farm dogs with gypsy dogs in the 1700s to produce the Old Danish Pointer. These bloodlines produced a breed with excellent scent-detecting and pointing abilities.

special.exercise: This is an energetic breed that requires a fair amount of exercise. As long as the Old Danish Pointer gets sufficient exercise, it will make a good family dog. However, this dog is not a good choice for apartment dwellers.
special.grooming: The Old Danish Pointer requires regular brushing and bathing.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorThe Old Danish Pointer is a pro at tracking, pointing and retrieving. The breed's quiet demeanor makes it a good family dog. This breed is also known for its courage and tenacity.

details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsHip dysplasia; bloat; tail deformities
details.history: History and Facts: This relatively new breed was created in 1971 by David Leavitt. He was unhappy with the breathing problems of the English Bulldog. As a result, he crossed half English Bulldog with half Bullmastiff, Pit Bull and American Bulldog to develop the Old English Bulldogge.

special.exercise: The Old English Bulldogge should not be encouraged to jump or exercise vigorously as puppies. They will maintain good muscle tone with light exercise.
special.grooming: No special grooming requirements.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorThis breed is friendly around family and friends but aggressive towards strangers. They can be intimidating to anyone threatening their family or property. Obedience is not this fearless dog's strong suit, making it a poor choice for first-time pet owners.

details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsOwners must have ability to meet the breeds high exercise and grooming needs. Breed-related health problems include hip dysplasia; cataracts; progressive retinal atrophy; cervical vertebral instability; bloat; deafness.
details.history: History and Facts:

special.exercise: The Old English Sheepdog is a herding dog that needs long daily play sessions and walks. The breed is best suited to a home with a yard.
special.grooming: The Old English Sheepdog needs extensive daily grooming in order to look its best. If neglected even for a short time, the shaggy coat will mat and / or accumulate debris.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorThe Old English Sheepdog is a gentle, well-mannered, fun-loving family dog. However, early socialization and training is needed. The breed thrives on human companionship. Although protective of its household, the Old English Sheepdog interacts well with strangers. Without proper attention, this breed can become unmanageable and stubborn.

details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsNot suited for city / apartment dwellers. Breed-related health problems: hip or elbow dysplasia; bloat; canine thrombocytopathy.
details.history: History and Facts: Although the exact origination of the Otter Hound is unknown, it is believed to have developed in the 1200s in France where it was bred to hunt otters that were depleting fish from the local streams. Despite being an ancient breed, it is relatively unpopular and is nearly extinct.

special.exercise: The Otter Hound prefers the outdoors and needs plenty of exercise. These dogs enjoy swimming, romps in the yard and long walks on a leash.
special.grooming: Otter Hounds have a dense, coarse coat that requires daily grooming.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorThe Otter Hound is a sweet-natured, vocal and sociable dog. This breed tends to get along well with humans and other pets. However, it may chase stray cats and other small animals. Otter Hounds have a stubborn, independent streak and may be somewhat difficult to train.

details.aka: Also know as: Epagneul Nain, Continental Toy Spaniel
details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsPatellar luxation; deafness
details.history: History and Facts: The papillon was developed as a companion dog for royalty during the 1500s. Marie Antoinette and Madame de Pompadour were early lovers and owners of this breed.

special.exercise: The papillon needs little exercise, but will enjoy long, brisk walks.
special.grooming: The papillon needs groomed several times per week, as well as trimmed quarterly (every 3 months).

details.temperament: Temperament / Behaviorpapillon's are gentle, friendly dogs that can be easily trained. If socialized early, this breed will adore children and other pets.

details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsTearing of the eyes; breathing problems; progressive retinal atrophy; hip dysplasia; patellar luxation; Legg-Calves-Perth disease.
details.history: History and Facts: Developed in the United States during the 1950s.

special.exercise: No special exercise requirements.
special.grooming: The Peekapoo requires daily brushing to prevent matting.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorTends to be a docile and fairly inactive pet that gets along well with children and other animals. Peekapoos are known to be less aggressive than the Cockapoo.

details.aka: Also know as: Chinese Lion Dog, Pekes
details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsUmbilical hernias; eye problems; patellar luxation; undescended testicles; intervertbral disc protrusion; breathing problems due to deformities of nose and mouth
details.history: History and Facts: The Pekinese is an ancient breed that was favored by the Chinese Imperial Court.

special.exercise: No special exercise requirements.
special.grooming: The Pekingese requires daily brushing and combing. The Pekinese has a soft, long, straight coat with a thick undercoat.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorThe Pekinese is a playful, loyal, intelligent and opinionated dog that makes a good-natured companion for its owner. Some Pekinese can be independent and stubborn, which can make training difficult. Pekinese tend to be cautious of strangers and children under the age of 10. While this breed may be a bit aggressive or aloof with other dogs, they tend to be good with cats. Good alarm barkers.

details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsBladder stones; epilepsy; hip dysplasia; progressive retinal atrophy; eye disorders; in vertebral disc protrusion
details.history: History and Facts: Although the origin of this breed is hard to trace, it was most likely brought to the British Isles by Flemish weavers. Developed in Pembrokeshire, Wales, the high-stamina dog was bred to herd cattle, sheep and even horses. It become popular among British royalty (Queen Anne II and King George VI).

special.exercise: The Pembroke Welsh Corgi will need daily walking, play and / or herding session. This dog is best suited to suburban or rural homes so that it has access to a yard.
special.grooming: Weekly brushing to remove dead hair is required for your Pembroke Welsh Corgi

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorPembroke Welsh Corgis are intelligent, easily trained dogs. This breed tends to make an extremely good family dog, as well as a good watchdog. The breed integrates well with other pets, including cats -- especially if socialized at an early age.  However, if there are two male Corgis in a household, they will tend to fight. This breed is active with plenty of stamina.

details.aka: Also know as: Inca Hairless, Perro Sin Pello Del Peru, Perros Flora, Ca-Allepo
details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsExcellent health record. No known hereditary conditions.
details.history: History and Facts: The exact heritage of the Peruvian Incan Orchid is unknown. However, it is an ancient breed thought to have originated around 750 A.D. Incan nobility favored these dog; the breed is thought to have earned its current name when the Spanish conquered the Incas because they were discovered in orchid patches.

special.exercise: The Peruvian Inca Orchid is an active breed that requires several long walks and play sessions per day.
special.grooming: No special grooming requirements.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorThis breed tends to be quiet and reserved with strangers. Early socialization and obedience training is necessary.

details.aka: Also know as: Little Griffon Vedeen Basset
details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsHypothyroidism; allergies; epilepsy; ear infections
details.history: History and Facts: This breed has its roots in 16th century France, where it were used to hunt wild hare. Recognized by the AKC in 1990, the breed has become quite popular among dog fanciers.

special.exercise: The Petit Basset Griffon Vendeen requires several walks and play sessions per day.
special.grooming: Weekly grooming is required is required for your Petit Basset Griffon Vendeen.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorThe Petit Basset Griffon Vendee is a happy, sociable breed that performs well in obedience classes - especially if socialized early. If treated gently, this breed gets along well with children. Although somewhat possessive, this breed also integrates well with other pets, but exhibits a tendency to bark. The Petit Basset Griffon Vendeen adapts well to life in almost any household environment as long as it gets plenty of exercise.

details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsCardiovascular disease; gastrointestinal disorders
details.history: History and Facts: Another one of the most ancient dog breeds, the Pharaoh Hound has been around for more than three thousand centuries. These dogs may have been introduced to Malta by early travelers from Greece and North Africa. This breed closely resembles the Egyptian god of dogs, Anubis.

special.exercise: Pharaoh Hounds are extremely energetic dogs that require plenty of space, exercise and human interaction.
special.grooming: The Pharaoh Hound needs weekly grooming.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorPharaoh Hounds are eager-to-please and tend to perform well in obedience training. This is a timid breed, so early socialization is necessary. Pharaoh Hounds love to chase small children, but can be trained to live with cats. Most Pharaoh Hounds make great additions to a family and get along with well children, as long as they receive plenty of exercise.

details.aka: Also know as: Berger Picard, Berger de Picardie
details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsExcellent health record. No known hereditary conditions.
details.history: History and Facts: The breed originated in France during the Middle Ages, but nearly became extinct after WWI and WWII. Today the breed is still extremely rare; there are only about 5000 registered dogs in the world.

special.exercise: No special exercise requirements.
special.grooming: No special grooming requirements.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorThe Picardy Shepherd is a reliable and affectionate family dog that responds well to obedience training. It has been primarily bred as a good farm dog.

details.aka: Also know as: The German word for Terrier, Pinscher refers to the category of breeds that included the Doberman Pinscher, German Pinscher, Affenpinscher, Austrian Short-Haired Pinscher, Carlin Pinscher, Harlequin Pinscher, Miniature Pinscher and Swiss Shorthaired Pinsc

details.aka: Also know as: American Pit Bull Terrier
details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsRequires an experienced dog owner. Be sure to choose a reputable breeder to avoid behavioral problems (aggressiveness) and health problems.
details.history: History and Facts: The Pit Bull was developed in the United States during the 1800s. It is the result of a cross between the Staffordshire Bull Terrier and an extinct fighting Bulldog. It was originally bred for dog fighting.

special.exercise: The Pit Bull is an active breed that requires several long walks and play sessions each day. They will appreciate a yard where they can run and romp.
special.grooming: Brushing once per week is required for your Pit Bull.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorThe Pit Bull can be a wonderful family companion if provided with early socialization and obedience training. This dog can be bred for gentleness. However, Pit Bulls are often bred to fight. Therefore many street Pit Bulls are aggressive: They have been taught to main or kill. Before you purchase a Pit Bull, be sure it is permitted by your local government and that you are working with a reputable breeder.

details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsBloat
details.history: History and Facts: The Plott Hound originated in North Carolina during the 1700s when the Plott brothers brought their dogs with them when they immigrated from Germany.

special.exercise: The Plott Hound is an active breed that requires several long walks and play sessions per day.
special.grooming: No special grooming requirements.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorPlott Hounds tend to be eager-to-please, loyal and intelligent.  Although it's generally a consistent breed, there are some differences in temperament between the coonhound variety and the one developed to hunt big game. The Plott Hound is a courageous, but somewhat stubborn, breed with plenty of stamina. It is rarely kept as just a companion dog.

details.aka: Also know as: Polish Owczarek Nizinny, PON
details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsRequires an experienced dog owner. Breed-related health problems include: patent ductus arteriosus.
details.history: History and Facts: Although its exact origins are unknown, the PON is thought to be a descendant of the Tibetan Terrier and Hungarian Sheepdog.

special.exercise: The Polish Owczarek Nizinny is an active breed that needs several long play sessions and walks per day.
special.grooming: Like the Old English Sheepdog, the PON needs extensive daily grooming. Otherwise, the wooly fur will mat and accumulate debris.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorExtremely loyal and protective of its family, the PON has a tendency to bark. Although wary of strangers, the breed is an affectionate one that gets along well with children if socialized early. The PON is independent and has a stubborn streak, so firm, confident handling is necessary during training. This breed is an active one that will need a job in order to be fulfilled.

details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsUndescended testicles; patellar luxation; tracheal collapse; patent ductus arteriosus; progressive retinal atrophy; hypoglycemia; tooth and gum disease. Be sure to obtain your Pomeranian from a reputable dealer.
details.history: History and Facts: The Pomeranian is thought to be a descendant of the large German Spitz. Even though it is a small dog, the Pomeranian believes it is just as big as other dogs. The Pomeranian gained popularity after Queen Victoria brought one home from England.

special.exercise: The Pomeranian needs little exercise.
special.grooming: Pomeranians needs brushed several times per week, as well as trimmed about every 12 weeks.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorPomeranians are spunky dogs that tend to perform well in obedience classes. If not well-trained and socialized early, Pomeranians may be unfriendly to strangers, other dogs, and family members. This dog will bark to guard its property. This breed adapts well to apartment living and is well-suited for adult households.

details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsExcellent health record. No known hereditary conditions.
details.history: History and Facts: Thought to have originated in the 19th century in the Pont-Audemer region of France. This breed has Poodle, Barbet and old Spaniel ancestry. The breed nearly became extinct after World War II but was revived by breeding with the Irish Water Spaniel.

special.exercise: The Pont-audemer Spaniel is an active breed that requires several long walks and play sessions per day.
special.grooming: The Pont-audemer requires daily brushing to prevent matting.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorThe Pont-Audemer Spaniel is a gentle, affectionate breed that thrives on work. Fun-loving and easily trained, this breed is nicknamed the "Clowns of the Marshes."

details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsPoodles are prone to several health problems, so it is important to obtain yours from a reputable breeder. Common breed-related health problems include: Atopy; eye problems; deafness; patellar luxation; heart and blood disorders; epilepsy; Cushing's syndrome
details.history: History and Facts: The Poodle has been around since the Middle Ages. It originated in Germany, where it was used as a water retriever and sometimes, a circus clown. The word Poodle is derived from "pfudel", the German word for "puddle." The Toy and Miniature Poodles were developed in England during the 1700s. The Miniature Poodle was bred from the Standard Poodle and, like its larger ancestor, was first used in France as a water fowl retriever and a truffle hunter.

special.exercise: The Poodle is an active dog that will need plenty of exercise. These dogs will need a secured yard in which to play and / or several walks per day.
special.grooming: Poodles do not shed. However, they still need to be brushed several times per week. The coat will need to be clipped and shaped every 4 - 6 weeks.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorPoodles are one of the most intelligent dog breeds. This breed enjoys working, and is highly responsive, playful and affectionate. In most cases, the Poodle is easily trained. Although Poodles tend to bark at strangers, the breed is not aggressive. Toy and Miniature Poodles are more reserved around strangers and less tolerant of children. In addition, they can be more prone to biting. For the best temperament, socialize your Poodle early; it is a social breed that needs plenty of interaction.

details.aka: Also know as: Chien de Franche-Comte
details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsExcellent health record. No known hereditary conditions.
details.history: History and Facts: The breed originated in France during the 1600s, but was nearly extinct after the French Revolution. The breed was refreshed by breeding with the Swiss Hound. It is still somewhat rare and almost exclusively found in France or Switzerland.

special.exercise: The Porcelaine is an active breed that requires several long walks and play sessions per day.
special.grooming: No special grooming requirements.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorThe Porcelaine is an active breed that makes a friendly, loving companion, as well as a keen hunting dog.

details.aka: Also know as: Portuguese Rabbit Dog
details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsPatellar Luxation (dislocation of the kneecap)
details.history:
History and Facts: The Portuguese Podengo Grande's roots date back to 1,000 B.C. when a group of ancient hound dogs came to the Iberian Peninsula. They were developed to hunt throughout the harsh terrain in Portugal and dig their way through thick bushes to catch their prey. According to the Portuguese Podengo Club of America, the breed traveled aboard ships of Christopher Columbus, Vasco da Gama and Magellan. The breed comes in three sizes: Grande (large), Medio (medium) and Pequeno (small). Although the AKC does not recognize varieties, in Portugal, the breed is divided into six varieties: 
Grande Smooth,
Grande Wire,
Medio Smooth,
Medio Wire,
Pequeno Smooth,
Pequeno Wire,
The wirehaired coat is medium-long, shaggy and coarse. The smooth coat is longer than most hound dogs.

special.exercise: This active breed requires a lot of daily exercise including long, brisk walks or jogs.
special.grooming: No special grooming requirements.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorPortuguese Podengo Grandes are a happy, intelligent and active breed. They enjoy the company of other dogs and humans of all ages. They are also very good guard dogs and barking is not uncommon when a stranger approaches the home.

details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsRequires an experienced dog owner. Breed-related health problems: progressive retinal atrophy; glycogen storage disease; kidney problems; Addison's disease; cardiomyopathy; follicular dysplasia.
details.history: History and Facts: The Portuguese Water Dog is most likely of Poodle heritage. It originated during the Middle Ages to help fisherman retrieve broken nets, herd schools of fish and carry messages from ship to shore.

special.exercise: The Portuguese Water Dog needs a long walk or play session each day, as well as frequent opportunities to swim.
special.grooming: The Portuguese Water Dog requires brushing several times per week, as well as bi-monthly trimming and grooming.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorThe Portuguese Water Dog loves water and is known as a devoted family dog that's especially good with children. Portuguese Water Dogs are good swimmers, highly intelligent and playful. The breed needs early socialization and obedience training. This dog will tend to bark and makes a good watchdog. This breed is a good fit for people that desire an active, affectionate, amiable companion.

details.history: History and Facts: The origination of the Posavac Hound is unknown. However, it is believed that these dogs were introduced to the Balkan region by Egyptian traders. It has been used to hunt hares, other small game and deer.

special.exercise: No special exercise requirements.
special.grooming: No special grooming requirements.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorThis is a lively alert breed with a gentle nature. Posavatz Hounds are known to be good companions.

details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsExcellent health record. No known hereditary conditions.
details.history: History and Facts: This breed is a Molosser type that was bred to be a good farm dog, cattle herder and watchdog. It is thought to be a descendant of the Perro de Bardino Majorero, Mastiff and old style Bulldog that originated in the 1700s. It is part of the AKC registered Foundation Stock Service.

special.exercise: No special exercise requirements.
special.grooming: No special grooming requirements.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorThe Perro de Presa Canary is known for its calm temperament. It is an intelligent, gentle loving companion that's wary of strangers and protective of its family. In some rare cases, this breed is aggressive toward other animals and humans. In the last five years, two females have been mauled to death by this breed. It is a dominant breed that will need early socialization and obedience training. Not recommended for inexperienced dog owners.

details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsExcellent health record. No known hereditary conditions.
details.history: History and Facts: The breed was developed from seven Poodles and more than 100 Pointers by Baron von Zedlitz, a German hunter and dog breeder. This breed is extremely rare, even in its native Germany, these dogs are only owned by serious hunters. For some unknown reason, the Pudlepointer has never been a popular breed.

special.exercise: No special exercise requirements.
special.grooming: No special grooming requirements.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorThe Pudlepointer is an excellent breed with no major faults.

details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsExcellent health record. No known hereditary conditions.
details.history: History and Facts: The Pyrenean Mastiff is probably a cross between the Spanish Mastiff and the Great Pyrenees. All can trace their heritage back to the Asiatic Mastiffs.

special.exercise: No special exercise requirements.
special.grooming: No special grooming requirements.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorThe Pyrenean Mastiff makes an obedient, reliable and protective companion.

details.history: History and Facts: This breed is a mix of old time Fox Terriers and other European Terriers common in the 19th century. By the early 1900s, the Rat Terrier was one of the most common farm dogs used for ratting, hunting varmints and other related work. Today, Rat Terriers come in two size divisions: Standard and Miniature. Neither size has weight limits but do have size limits.  Miniatures should be at least 10 inches, but should not exceed 13 inches. Standards are over 13 inches, and up to 18 inches in height. The Rat Terrier is slightly longer than tall.

special.exercise: The Rat Terrier is an active breed that requires several long walks and play sessions per day.
special.grooming: No special grooming requirements.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorThe Rat Terrier is a gentle dog with strong hunting instincts. The breed is generally friendly with other dogs, but may be reserved with strangers. Many excel in agility and obedience events.

details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsRequires an experienced dog owner. Breed-related health problems: hip dysplasia; dermoid sinus; deafness.
details.history: History and Facts: The Rhodesian Ridgeback is a mix of a ridgebacked dog owned by the Hottentot people of South Africa and European mastiffs, scent hounds, Great Danes and Greyhounds. The breed became popular in the 1920s when it was taken to Rhodesia to hunt lions.

special.exercise: The Rhodesian Ridgeback is best suited for suburban or rural homes that have a yard. This breed requires a significant amount of rigorous exercise each day.
special.grooming: The Rhodesian Ridgeback needs little grooming.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorThe Rhodesian Ridgeback is a loyal guard dog, as well as an exceptional hunter. With proper training and early socialization, this breed makes a good family dog that gets along well with children. However, these dogs can be too rambunctious for smaller kids. This is an active breed that needs daily mental and physical exercise in order to feel satisfied. The Rhodesian Ridgeback can be wary of strangers and is sometimes aggressive toward other animals.

details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsHip or elbow dysplasia; parvovirus; deafness; neurological disorders; kidney failure; bloat. Not recommended for inexperienced dog owners.
details.history: History and Facts: The Rottweiler is an ancient breed that has roots in the Roman empire. The breed was used as herding dogs for the cattle that accompanied the Roman army during its travels. At one point in time, the breed was nearly extinct. However, the breed was standardized in the early 1900s and now is the second most popular dog breed.

special.exercise: Rottweilers need considerable exercise and are best raised in the suburbs or country where they are able to run.
special.grooming: No special grooming requirements.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorRottweilers are known to be highly protective dogs. While the breed is loyal, confident and generally calm, your Rottweiler will need daily exercise, strict obedience training and early socialization. This breed tends to be domineering and some cannot be trusted around small dogs or cats. A Rottweiler may respond in an overly-protective way if it feels its family is being threatened. Avoid playing aggressive games with Rottweilers. These dogs enjoy being mentally challenged and are somewhat dependent on their owners for happiness.

details.health: Breed-Related Health ConcernsHip dysplasia
details.history: History and Facts: Originated in the cold regions of northern Scotland in the 1800s, the breed was made popular by Queen Victoria and the television show "Lassie."

special.exercise: No special exercise requirements.
special.grooming: The Rough Collie needs daily grooming.

details.temperament: Temperament / BehaviorThe Rough Collie is known for its intelligent, extremely kind temperament. It loves human companionship and is extremely tolerant of other animals. This breed may tend to be independent and prefer the companionship of its chosen human. It is a quick learner that adapts well to routines.
